poem:
**Heat Pump Blues**

Frost fingers tap at windowpane's chill,  
Power's out, shivering in electric silence,  
A heat pump's promise falls bitter and still,  
Plumbers shrug in cold defiance.  
What wood won't do to tame these icy tears,  
Warmed voices sing to furniture pyres,  
Winter's breath, a howling choir,  
Logbooks doomed to fiery postscript.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "How to make the heat-pump transition take off | Letters I have a heat pump (Letters, 5 January). It’s not much use to me today as the electricity is out because of the bad weather, my house is beyond cold and what I’d give for a fire – at least I could burn furniture to keep my family warm! Our heat pump has broken down on several occasions and no local plumber can deal with it". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
